newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Tough going at Bangladesh Hill Tracts peace talks.
newsitem.headline: Tough going at Bangladesh Hill Tracts peace talks.

text.p: A third day of talks aimed at ending a decades-old separatist insurgency in Bangladesh's Chittagong Hill Tracts ended on Tuesday apparently without reaching any conclusions.
A security official told reporters outside the conference hall that the talks would resume on Wednesday. Officials could not say if any progress had been made.
More than 8,500 civilians, rebels and soldiers have been killed in a bush war started by tribal Shanti Bahini guerrillas in 1973.
Attempts to strike a peace deal since Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina took office last June have yet to bear any fruit, officials said.

The Shanti Bahini want the 5,500 square miles (14,200 square km) of hill tracts in the southeast of the country to be officially designated as a tribal homeland with full autonomy, and some 500,000 Bengali-speaking settlers to be expelled from the region, which borders India and Burma.
The negotiations in Dhaka began hours behind schedule, with no official reason given for the delay.
A police officer told reporters around 8:30 p.m. (2030 local) that the negotiators had left the conference hall "through the back doors."
"Apparently they had nothing to report," a security official said.
The government side at the talks is being headed by Abdul Hasant Abdullah, parliamentary chief whip of the ruling Awami League.
Heading the rebel side is Jyotirindra Budhipriya Larma, chief of the Shanti Bahini's political wing, Parbatya Chattagram Janasanghati Samity (PCJSS).
The current meeting is the third with government leaders since January, but meeting sources said a breakthrough was still awaited.
The government has already started reclaiming tribal land and restoring it to thousands of tribal refugees who returned home in the first phase of a repatriation programme in March and April.
But the government has refused to expel the Bengalis, fearing a severe backlash, Hill Tracts officials said.

"The negotiations have hit rough ground on the issue of land rights of the tribes and their demand for a constitutional guarantee for special status of the tribal population," one meeting source said.
The settlers launched a strike in Hill Tracts on Sunday as the talks began in Dhaka against what they said was the government's willingness to give undue concessions to the tribals.
The government, however, said it would do nothing that encroached upon the rights of the settlers.
